dialogue.raw_text: I need to correct an impression. Dieter said yesterday this was about justice. But is it? (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) If it were about justice you might ask why has it taken so long? The war ended twenty years ago. Remember, there've been no significant trials between Nuremburg in 1946 and the Auschwitz trials a couple of years ago. That's a long gap. What's the reason for the gap?

dialogue.raw_text: Say.

dialogue.raw_text: Cowardice. It's cowardice, isn't it? It's bad conscience. It's the big cover-up.

dialogue.raw_text: Go on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: After the war. The German people didn't want to look at what they'd done.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Because they had too much to hide. All our parents are liars. All right, mine are. So it's left to us, isn't it?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, but seriously, Dieter's right. My parents, I can't even talk to them. I don't love them. How could I? How could anyone love them? Because they've told themselves so many lies, they can't remember the truth, let alone admit it. Isn't that why we signed up for this seminar?

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know. You tell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Speaking for myself.

dialogue.raw_text: Michael?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I mean, that's what I'm saying. So were a million other Germans.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Societies think they operate by something called morality. But they don't. They operate by something called law. You're not guilty of anything merely by working at Auschwitz. 8,000 people worked at Auschwitz. Precisely 19 have been convicted, and only 6 for murder. To prove murder you have to prove intent. That's the law. Remember, the question is never `Was it wrong?' but `Was it legal?' And not by our laws, no, by the laws at the time.

direction.raw_text: frowns, unhappy.

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. The law is narrow.

direction.raw_text: looks unapologetic.

dialogue.raw_text: On the other hand, I suspect people who kill other people tend to be aware that it's wrong.

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, it's right.

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sure you understand...

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Her. And her. And her. And her. And her. And her.

dialogue.raw_text: Each of the guards would choose a certain number of women. Hanna Schmitz chose differently.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In what way differently?

dialogue.raw_text: She had favourites. Girls, mostly young. We all remarked on it, she gave them food and places to sleep. In the evening, she asked them to join her. We all thought - well, you can imagine what we thought.

At first we thought this guard, this guard is more sensitive, she's more human, she's kinder. Often she chose the weak, the sick, she picked them out, she seemed to be protecting them almost. But then she dispatched them. Is that kinder?

direction.raw_text: looks back, not apologizing.

dialogue.raw_text: I want to move on now to the march. As I understand it, you and your daughter were marched for many months.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. It was the winter of 1944. Our camp was closed down, we were told we had to move on. But the plan kept changing every day. Women were dying all around us in the snow. Half of us died on the march. My daughter says in the book, less a death march, more a death gallop.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks along the row to where ILANA is now sitting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please tell us about the night in the church.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: watches as ROSE looks across to ILANA. ILANA stares back at her. MICHAEL watches the exchange as ROSE nods, as if accepting she must go ahead and speak.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: That night we actually thought we were lucky because we had a roof over our heads. We'd arrived in a village, as always, the guards took the best quarters, they took the priest's house. But they let us sleep in a church. There was a bombing raid. In the middle of the night. At first we could only hear the fire, it was in the steeple. Then we could see burning beams, and they began to crash to the floor. Everyone rushed, rushed to the doors. But the doors had been locked on the outside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The church burned down? Nobody came to open the doors? Is that right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nobody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even though you were all burning to death?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: nods.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How many people were killed?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everyone was killed.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you survive?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I needed to get away from the other women. Because they were panicking, they were screaming. I couldn't stand it. I couldn't stand their screaming. I was more frightened of the other women than I was of the fire. So I too my daughter and led her to the upper floor. I can't defend what I did. It's impossible to defend. I took Ilana in my arms and I led her towards the fire. There was a small gallery at the side of the church on the upper level. It saved our lives. The gallery didn't burn.

direction.raw_text: turns, in tears, to look at ILANA.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. I want to thank you for coming to this country today to testify.

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you?

direction.raw_text: is very still, like an analyst who is finally leading his patient to the heart of things.

dialogue.raw_text: This didn't happen to the Germans. It happened to the Jews.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You choose six women, you put them on trial, you say `They were the evil ones, they were the guilty ones'. Brilliant! (MORE)
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (cont'd) Because one of the victims happened to write a book! That's why they're on trial and nobody else. Do you know how many camps there were in Europe?

direction.raw_text: turns, furious.

direction.raw_text: One of the group walks out.

dialogue.raw_text: People go on about how much did everyone know? `Who knew?' `What did they know?' That isn't the question. The question is `How could you let it happen?' And - better - `Why didn't you kill yourself when you found out?'

dialogue.raw_text: Thousands! That's how many. There were thousands of camps. Everyone knew.

direction.raw_text: passion is so great that everyone is shaken.

dialogue.raw_text: Hanna has been in prison for over twenty years. She has no family. She has no friends. You're her only contact. And I'm told you don't visit her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . KREUZBERG. DAY MICHAEL is sitting quite still.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No. I don't.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY MS BRENNER When she gets out, she's going to need a job. She's going to need somewhere to live. You can't imagine how frightening the modern world will seem to her. There is a silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. I'm still here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . KREUZBERG. DAY MS BRENNER I have no-one else to ask. If you don't take responsibility for her, then Hanna has no future at all.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It's kind of you. Thank you for letting me know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: puts the phone down. He looks as if he has just been handed a sentence. He gets up and stares at the wall which is now stacked with all the books he has read. Then he goes to his balcony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: & INT. MICHAEL'S APARTMENT. KREUZBERG. DAY MICHAEL stands looking out over Berlin from his balcony.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY MICHAEL walks along the road by the prison wall, then goes to the guichet to sign in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY MICHAEL is waiting in a small barred waiting area as MS BRENNER walks across the yard to open the gate and let
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You're Michael Berg?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Louisa Brenner. We were expecting you earlier.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: & EXT. STAIRS & PASSAGE. PRISON. DAY MS BRENNER is walking MICHAEL up the steps towards the prison canteen. They pass GUARDS and INMATES.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I should warn you: for a long time Hanna held herself together. She was very purposeful. In the last few years she's different. She's let herself go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . PRISON. DAY MS BRENNER leads MICHAEL to the door of the canteen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They're in the canteen. They're just finishing lunch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: sees an OLD WOMAN who is sitting at a table. Her blue dress is stretched too tight across her heavy body. Her hair is grey. She has a book in her lap, but she's not reading it. A few PRISONERS are finishing their meal. It takes MICHAEL a moment to realise the OLD WOMAN is HANNA. Then HANNA becomes aware of being watched. She turns and looks round. At once her face lights up. MICHAEL smiles back, but as he approaches her, he fixes onto her inquiring look and sees the light go out of her eyes, as if she has looked at him and been disappointed. He sits down opposite her. She smiles, weary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She takes his hand. There is a long silence, MICHAEL unable to think of anything to say. He withdraws his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a moment's silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You've grown up, kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've got a friend who's a tailor, he makes my suits. He'll give you a job. And I've found you somewhere to live. It's a nice place. Quite small but nice. I think you'll like it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There are various social programmes, cultural stuff I can sign you up for. And there's a public library very close.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: nods slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a short silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You read a lot?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I prefer being read to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's over now, isn't it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: doesn't answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: After a few moments, he concedes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . There is a silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Did you get married?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did. Yes I did. We have a daughter. I'm not seeing as much of her as I would like. I'd like to see a great deal more of her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The marriage didn't last.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have you spent a lot of time thinking about the past?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean, with you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No. No, I didn't mean with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Before the trial I never thought about the past. I never had to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And now? What do you feel now?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks a moment, a haunting look, searching him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a silence.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: It doesn't matter what I think. It doesn't matter what I feel. The dead are still dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wasn't sure what you'd learnt.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I have learnt, kid. I've learnt to read.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: stares, devastated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . They look at each other. The other PRISONERS have already gone. They stand up. She scans his face again, searching for his thoughts. He takes her in his arms, a little awkward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk side by side, back towards the door. Then by way of saying goodbye, she takes his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stretches her arm out before she lets go of his hand, then vanishes inside. MICHAEL walks on alone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll pick you up next week, OK?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That sounds a good plan.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good. Quietly, or shall we make a big fuss?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Quietly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: . Quietly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Take care, kid.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: See you next week.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . EVE MICHAEL comes out of the main entrance. He stands a moment, looking round at the evening. MICHAEL walks to his car.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVE The room is simple, a bedroom to one side, a bathroom to the other. It is all furnished with simple functional furniture. The end of a hard day's work. MICHAEL hangs a picture over the desk - a landscape, reminiscent of where they once went cycling. The job is done. He looks round, grimly content.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAWN HANNA is lying on her bed, fully dressed. She gets up and gets some books down from the shelf. She puts them, one by one, in a pile on the table. Then she takes off her shoes. She stands up and climbs onto the pile of books on the table. Her bare feet on the books. Then she reaches up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: & INT. PRISON. DAY MICHAEL gets out of the car. He is carrying a bunch of flowers. He walks towards the prison. He leans in to the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: who is in a modern office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY From the far end of the corridor, MICHAEL is seen sitting on a bench. MS BRENNER comes out of her office and murmurs in his ear. MICHAEL is seen nodding, ashen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: & CELL. PRISON. DAY The two of them come together down the corridor. They stop at the open door of the cell. The body has been removed. The books are still on the floor. MICHAEL goes in. A bare table, a chair, a bed, a closet, a toilet in the corner behind the door. There are shelves with books, an alarm clock, a stuffed bear, two mugs, instant coffee, tea tins.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She didn't pack. She never intended to leave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks at him in confirmation. MICHAEL looks at the two lower shelves on which are ranged the tapes with the cassette machine. Above the bed are a series of cuttings, pictures torn from magazines, showing meadows, hillsides, pasture, cherry trees. One in particular : a burst of autumnal colours. MICHAEL kneels on the bed to look at them. There are quotations, articles, recipes, even sayings in HANNA'S childish handwriting : `Spring lets its blue banner flutter through the air' is one. Then he sees a newspaper photograph : the young MICHAEL BERG receiving a prize from the school principal. The headline `Michael Berg receives school literature prize.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: reaches out for a tea tin from the shelf. Then she sits next to MICHAEL on the bed, and takes out a folded sheet of paper from her suit pocket.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She left me a message, a sort of will. I'll read out the bit that concerns you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks at the effortful handwriting on the page.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: "There is money in the old tea tin. Give it to Michael Berg. He should send it, alongside the 7,000 marks in the bank, to the daughter who wrote the book. It's for her. She should decide what to do with it. And tell Michael I said hello. Tell him to get on with his life."
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks at him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Do you want to see her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . MANHATTAN. DAY MICHAEL rides in a taxi into Manhattan. A view of the familiar skyline.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY MICHAEL'S taxi comes up Fifth Avenue. It draws up outside an expensive apartment block. MICHAEL gets out and goes in, the Manhattan skyline opening up behind him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . ILANA'S APARTMENT. DAY A superbly appointed space full of great and expensive art.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: has taken his coat off. ILANA MATHER appears, elegant, well-dressed - on the surface, the spirit of prosperous New York. She is now in her early fifties.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ms Mather?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. You're Michael Berg. I was expecting you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So you must tell me: what exactly brings you to the United States?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was already here. I was at a conference in Boston.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a lawyer?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was intrigued by your letter but I can't say I wholly understood it. You attended the trial?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes. Almost twenty years ago. I was a law student. I remember you, I remember your mother very clearly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: My mother died in Israel - a good many years ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: hesitates for a moment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Go on, please.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Perhaps you heard. Hanna Schmitz recently died. She killed herself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She was a friend of yours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: A kind of friend. It's as simple as this. Hanna was illiterate for the greater part of her life.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Is that an explanation of her behaviour?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or an excuse?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: shakes his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: No. No. She taught herself to read when she was in prison. I sent her tapes. She'd always liked being read to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: shifts slightly.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you start by being honest with me? At least start that way. What was the nature of your friendship?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When I was young I had an affair with Hanna.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks at him for a moment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not sure I can help you, Mr. Berg. Or rather, even if I could I'm not willing to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was almost sixteen when I took up with her. The affair only lasted a summer. But.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: just looks at her.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I see. And did Hanna Schmitz acknowledge the effect she'd had on your life?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: stares back, understood for the first time.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: She'd done much worse to other people. I've never told anyone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: People ask all the time what I learned in the camps. But the camps weren't therapy. What do you think these places were? Universities? We didn't go there to learn. One becomes very clear about these things.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks at him, unrelenting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What are you asking for? Forgiveness for her? Or do you just want to feel better yourself? My advice, go to the theatre, if you want catharsis. Please. Go to literature. Don't go to the camps. Nothing comes out of the camps. Nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks at him, unrelenting.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What she wanted...what she wanted was to leave you her money. I have with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: To do what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As you think fit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: reaches for his briefcase. He takes out the lavender tea-tin, which he sets down on the table in front of ILANA.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: lifts the tin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sits a moment, overcome, her hand on the tin.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: When I was a little girl, I had a tea-tin for my treasures. Not quite like this. It had Cyrillic lettering. I took it with me to the camp, but it got stolen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was in it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh. Sentimental things. A piece of hair from our dog. Some tickets to operas my father had taken me to. It wasn't stolen for its contents. It was the tin itself which was valuable, what you could do with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There's nothing I can do with this money. If I give it to anything associated with the extermination of the Jews, then to me it will seem like absolution and that is something I'm neither willing nor in a position to grant.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: nods slightly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is the shadow of a smile.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I was thinking maybe an organization to encourage literacy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do you know if there's a Jewish organization?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll be surprised if there isn't. There's a Jewish organisation for everything. Not that illiteracy is a very Jewish problem.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why don't you find out? Send them the money.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shall I do it in Hanna's name?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As you think fit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: smiles slightly. She puts her hand on top of the tin.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I'll keep the tin.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY ILANA is standing at the window watching down to the street where MICHAEL is walking away. She has the tin in her hand. When he's vanished, she turns and goes into her bedroom. There on the dressing table, there is a framed photo of ILANA with her mother in Germany before the war. She sets the tin down beside the photo.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: & EXT. CAR. DAY 1995. MICHAEL is driving JULIA in the big Mercedes through the German countryside. He is tense, silent. JULIA takes a sideways look at him, but he does not respond.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Where are we going?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought you liked surprises.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I do. I do like surprises.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: . DAY They draw up at a church. It is the same one he and HANNA passed on their bicycles years before. MICHAEL and JULIA get out and walk towards the graveyard at the side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY MICHAEL & JULIA stand at a deserted grave-side. The whole cemetery is seen. MICHAEL stoops down and uncovers a simple stone : HANNA SCHMITZ 1923-1988. JULIA watching, says her name.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hanna Schmitz.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: waits a moment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Who was she?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's what I wanted to tell you. That's why we're here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: looks, waiting. MICHAEL looks for a moment as if he will not go on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a moment, then they turn to stroll, MICHAEL talking, starting to tell the story.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They walk away among the trees.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So tell me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was 15, I was coming home from school, I was ill...
dialogue.name: dialogue
